author: @ritosgale
text:
Latino (first-gen Mexican-American/Chicano with Mexican immigrant parents) here -- I'm not the Latino Lorax and I can only speak for myself, not the whole community üò≠ (i WISH we had a meeting amongst ourselves LMFAO) but I do have a tiny bit of insight.

There are honestly MANY complex and layered reasons for why latinos vote red in many areas. I see people in the comments mentioning colorism, which is obviously one of them. There's also the fact that there's a discrepancy between legal immigrants/naturalized citizens/US-born Latino-Americans and undocumented Latinos -- there's so much prejudice and hatred that many Latino citizens feel towards undocumented migrants which is often times a superiority complex. Along with that there's also racism and fighting among different groups -- I oftentimes hear my Democrat-voting Mexican parents and family members say questionable shit about Central Americans. Becoming a US citizen honestly brainwashes and erases a lot of people's experiences that they had with racism when they first moved here, especially the more time passes between someone's status as undocumented and someone's naturalization. You also have many immigrants from "socialist" nations (besides Cuba) who view Democrats as communists and vote accordingly.

When it comes to GOP support from Latinos along the border, I think that another layer to it is that there's many ICE agents who themselves are Latinos... which you can honestly apply what James Baldwin said about Black cops to such ICE agents (and any other Latinos in law enforcement, for that matter, who are also extremely racist and anti-Black). You also have the obvious reasons for some groups where they're extremely socially conservative due to the Catholic religion (when funnily enough, the Catholic Church as an institution openly opposes a lot of the GOP's psychotic shit) and that's self-explanatory.

People could write a whole dissertation about this, but I'm not an expert haha. Olay, I honestly invite you and encourage you to get into Latinos' business if you feel comfortable to do so. You don't have to speak on it publicly if you want to open that platform to people more knowledgable and outspoken on the subject, but it is probably important knowledge to have going forward since the Latino vote is more complex than people give it for in comparison to how other marginalized groups vote -- it's not as (for a lack of a better term) 'simple' as many Black Americans overwhelmingly supporting Democrats for obvious historic reasons -- and it'll likely be decisive in many elections going forward.

author: @andreaskye
text:
I can't even find the words to thank you enough! 
As a lifelong Texan who would leave if there weren't so many members of my family, I am horrified at the further into hell the state meanders each day.
 I was raised by a family that was progressive but mostly just not cruel. You wouldn't know there are more of us than them. More of us are decent people that just want everyone to be able to live. 
 I wake up each day feeling like I am in a nightmare. 
 I have been trying to vote these pigs out for years. I think voter apathy is the biggest downfall. Despair is everywhere.
 Most of us don't want to be a part of this in any way. But I think a large majority of us have lost hope to the point they don't even pay attention.
 I am 53, have worked all my adult life. I am at a critical point in my life healthwise yet I cannot access anything but the most basic emergency care and then cannot pay the hospital anyway. Because Abbott and his ilk just said no to the ACA. I am 1 of millions.
And the public is so numb, there was hardly any outcry!
The horror at the borders are hard to speak of. Honestly, it as if we are next door to the camp. 
Thank you again for laying it out for people. I already respected you and your work, now I add grateful to that!
